question: A 17-year-old gymnast reports fatigue, frequent bruising, and poor wound healing. Blood tests show a vitamin C deficiency. Which section of her small intestine is most likely impaired?
A 45-year-old male has a disease that prevents absorption of fat-soluble vitamins. He also has trouble digesting fatty foods. Where in the digestive tract is the issue most likely located?
A child with celiac disease has damage to the microvilli in his small intestine. Which of the following is the most likely direct consequence of this condition?
A patient has a condition in which epithelial cells lining the jejunum are damaged. Which of the following symptoms would most likely result?
options: Low energy due to reduced glucose uptake

question: A 32-year-old woman undergoes surgery that removes part of her ileum. Which of the following deficiencies is most likely to develop afterward?
options: Vitamin B12 and fat-soluble vitamin deficiency

question: A 14-year-old athlete faints during training. Blood tests show low glucose levels. The doctor explains his body has already used up stored glycogen. Which organ is responsible for this storage and glucose release?
A patient undergoing a high-protein diet shows elevated urea levels in the blood. What is the primary route by which the body eliminates this excess urea?
A medical student is examining a nephron under the microscope. Which of the following best describes its function?
A patient has severe dehydration. What hormone is likely to be released to influence kidney function and conserve water?
A child presents with swelling in the face and legs, and lab reports show protein in the urine. What structure in the kidney is most likely damaged?
A person has only one kidney after a surgical removal. Which of the following is true regarding their health status?
options: They cannot survive without hormone supplements
They can live a normal life with one kidney
They must avoid all protein-rich foods

question: Which of the following symptoms would most likely occur if the kidneys fail to maintain electrolyte balance?
A patient with kidney failure opts for peritoneal dialysis. What anatomical structure serves as the blood filter in this process?
After receiving a kidney transplant, a patient is prescribed immunosuppressant drugs. What is a major consequence of taking these drugs?
A gymnast sustains a spinal injury but still retains some ability to bend sideways. This suggests the injury most likely affected which structure without fully compromising flexibility?
options: The pivot joint in the neck
The fibrous joints in the skull
The ball-and-socket joint in the hip

question: A patient complains of shoulder pain and limited range of motion in all directions. Which joint is most likely affected?
A construction worker falls and damages the pivot joint between the top two vertebrae. Which of the following abilities would most likely be impaired?
options: Tilting the head forward and backward
Rotating the head left and right

question: A person has stiff knees with reduced ability to bend. What structure is most likely worn down, leading to bone-on-bone contact?
A child's skull bones are still forming. What type of joint connects the plates of their skull?
A person fractures their femur. Weeks later, doctors notice the bone is healing even though the patient is an adult. What cells are most responsible for this recovery?
A patient has dangerously low calcium levels in their blood. Which hormone will most likely increase, and what bone cells will it activate?
Why is it important that bones contain blood vessels, such as those found in Haversian canals?
options: They help transfer mechanical pressure into bone strength
They supply nutrients and remove waste from bone cells

question: A medical student argues that bones are not living tissue because they are hard and don't regenerate. How would you respond using evidence from the text?
options: Bones are mostly dead, but surrounded by skin
Bones produce blood and store minerals, which proves they are alive
Bones cannot regenerate after injury, so the student is right
Bones are only alive when you're a child

question: Why is calcification essential during embryonic development?
options: It allows the skull to grow

question: If the thyroid gland fails to produce calcitonin, what might happen to a person's bones over time?
options: Bones may overgrow due to excess calcium
Blood calcium levels may fall dangerously low
Osteoblasts would deposit too much calcium in bones
Bones may become brittle due to calcium loss

question: A person experiences a severe injury and loses a large amount of blood. How might their skeletal system help compensate?
options: Cartilage between ribs will contract to pump blood
Ligaments will transfer blood between bones
Yellow marrow will convert to red marrow to produce more blood cells
Compact bone will release stored blood

question: A person begins shivering in response to cold temperatures. What kind of muscle is responsible for this heat-generating response, and why is it effective?
options: Smooth muscle; it generates long-term sustained contractions
Cardiac muscle; it uses ATP rapidly to produce heat
Skeletal muscle; it contracts rapidly to release energy as heat
Fast-twitch muscle; it moves blood to the skin

question: Why does cardiac muscle have more mitochondria than skeletal muscle?
options: It is involuntary and can't rest
It doesn't produce as much ATP
It is less striated and uses more energy
It stores energy for skeletal muscles

question: What would most likely happen if calcium ions (Ca2+) were unable to bind to regulatory proteins during muscle contraction?
options: Myosin would stay bound to actin forever
Myosin could not bind to actin, and no contraction would occur
The muscle would become rigid and over-contracted

question: A new drug blocks the neuromuscular junction. What would be the result in terms of muscle contraction?
options: No calcium would be released, so muscles would not contract
Actin would break down, preventing movement
The heart would stop due to lack of blood flow

question: Which of the following best explains why muscles can only “pull” and not “push”?
options: Myosin filaments only rotate in one direction
Actin is only anchored at one end of the sarcomere
Muscle fibers contract (shorten), but cannot elongate
Calcium prevents the muscle from pushing

question: Which structure acts as the “anchor” for actin filaments during a contraction?
What would happen if the motor neuron failed to release neurotransmitters at the neuromuscular junction?
options: ATP would build up in the muscle

question: A patient presents with skin that is dry, flaky, and cracking, especially in areas exposed to frequent washing. Lab results show reduced oil secretion. Which part of the skin is most likely underperforming?
A child falls while playing and scrapes their knee. The area bleeds slightly and becomes red and swollen. Which layer of skin was primarily damaged in this injury?
A new drug blocks the neuromuscular junction. What would be the result in terms of muscle contraction?
options: No calcium would be released, so muscles would not contract
Actin would break down, preventing movement
The heart would stop due to lack of blood flow

question: Which of the following best explains why muscles can only “pull” and not “push”?
options: Myosin filaments only rotate in one direction
Actin is only anchored at one end of the sarcomere
Muscle fibers contract (shorten), but cannot elongate
Calcium prevents the muscle from pushing

question: Which structure acts as the “anchor” for actin filaments during a contraction?
What would happen if the motor neuron failed to release neurotransmitters at the neuromuscular junction?
options: ATP would build up in the muscle

question: A patient presents with skin that is dry, flaky, and cracking, especially in areas exposed to frequent washing. Lab results show reduced oil secretion. Which part of the skin is most likely underperforming?
A child falls while playing and scrapes their knee. The area bleeds slightly and becomes red and swollen. Which layer of skin was primarily damaged in this injury?
A construction worker notices that their hands have developed very thick and tough skin over time. Which protein is most responsible for this adaptation?
An elderly patient complains about wrinkles and loss of skin elasticity. What is the most likely cause of these age-related changes?
options: Clumping of collagen and reduction in elastin

question: If the body is exposed to a hot environment, how does the integumentary system help maintain homeostasis?
options: Hair follicles close to conserve moisture
Oil glands secrete more sebum to protect the skin
Sweat glands increase sweat production for evaporative cooling
Blood vessels constrict to reduce heat loss

question: A scientist blocks the function of melanocytes in lab animals. What effect would this most likely have?
options: Higher risk of UV damage to internal tissues

question: If a person has damage to the subcutaneous layer of the skin, which of the following consequences is most likely?
options: Poor temperature insulation and increased injury risk to internal organs

question: A 41-year-old man visits a dermatologist complaining of a patch of skin that has become darker and rougher in appearance over several months. He spends a lot of time outdoors without sunscreen. What might the doctor suspect is happening?
options: Melanin overproduction due to UV exposure

question: Which of the following changes in the integumentary system is most likely to occur with prolonged exposure to cold weather?
options: Increased sweating to cool the body
Constriction of blood vessels to conserve heat
Increased oil production to protect the skin

question: A 16-year-old girl is experiencing the onset of puberty. She begins to notice changes such as breast enlargement, widening of the pelvis, and increased body fat. Which hormone is primarily responsible for these changes?

A 22-year-old woman has been diagnosed with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which leads to irregular menstruation and elevated levels of testosterone. How might this condition affect her reproductive system?
options: It may prevent ovulation and cause difficulty in becoming pregnant.
It leads to overproduction of estrogen, causing early puberty.
It stimulates the development of more egg cells each month.
It increases the chances of fertilization and pregnancy.

question: A 25-year-old male is undergoing hormone replacement therapy to increase testosterone levels. Which of the following characteristics would most likely be enhanced by this therapy?
options: Increased muscle mass and body hair

question: A woman has been trying to conceive for several months without success. Upon examination, her ovaries are found to have underdeveloped egg cells. Which hormone deficiency might be responsible for this condition?

A 47-year-old male patient experiences a swelling in the scrotum and pain in the testicles. After examination, it is determined that the problem is related to an infection in the epididymis. What function of the epididymis is most likely affected?
A 15-year-old girl is just beginning her menstrual cycle. The release of which hormone is most directly responsible for the development and release of the egg from the ovary?

A male adolescent is undergoing puberty and begins to notice changes in his body, including deepening of his voice and increased muscle mass. Which hormone is most likely responsible for these changes?
A woman who is in her third trimester of pregnancy notices that she has stopped ovulating. What is the most likely cause of this absence of ovulation?
options: High levels of progesterone and estrogen

question: A male patient with a low sperm count is diagnosed with a testosterone deficiency. How might this deficiency affect his ability to produce sperm?
options: Testosterone stimulates the testes to produce sperm, so a deficiency could impair sperm production.
Testosterone decreases sperm motility, leading to infertility.
Testosterone increases the temperature in the testes, reducing sperm count.
Testosterone has no impact on sperm production.

question: During in vitro fertilization (IVF), multiple eggs are removed from a woman's ovaries. Which hormone is typically given beforehand to stimulate this process?
If LH is not released in sufficient amounts in females, what part of the menstrual cycle would be disrupted?
Why do testes hang outside the body in the scrotum?
options: To be closer to the urethra
To maintain a cooler temperature for sperm production

question: What would most likely happen if the pituitary gland did not release FSH at the beginning of the menstrual cycle?
options: The uterine lining would shed prematurely
A follicle would not develop and the egg would not mature
Progesterone levels would rise too quickly

question: During which phase is the endometrium most ready to receive a fertilized egg, and what hormone supports this?
What is the role of estrogen in the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle?
options: Trigger the breakdown of the uterine lining
Promote the thickening of the endometrium and increase LH levels
Prevent the maturation of other follicles

question: Why does only one egg typically mature and release each month, even though both ovaries contain many follicles?
options: One ovary is usually dominant and prevents the other from working
Hormonal feedback loops limit FSH and LH to one follicle
The uterus can only handle one egg at a time
The other eggs are not yet genetically ready

question: Which structure releases progesterone after ovulation, and what is its function?
options: Corpus luteum; prepares and maintains the endometrium
Ovary; causes the shedding of the uterine lining

question: What role does testosterone play in the male reproductive system?
options: It causes the release of the egg during ovulation
It initiates meiosis and the development of sperm cells
It prevents the production of sperm

question: Why do sperm need many mitochondria in their midpiece?
options: To provide energy for the flagellum to move
To carry DNA into the egg
To store proteins for the egg

question: A healthy couple has been trying to conceive for a year. The woman has regular cycles and ovulation confirmed through hormone testing. The man's semen analysis shows normal sperm count but unusually shaped sperm and low motility. Which structure in the sperm is most likely responsible for the low motility?
A male bodybuilder begins taking testosterone supplements. After a few months, he notices a decrease in testicular size and fertility. What is the physiological explanation for these symptoms?
options: Increased testosterone stimulates more sperm production
High external testosterone suppresses FSH and LH, reducing sperm production
Testosterone only affects muscles, not reproductive organs
Sperm cells cannot develop unless estrogen is present

question: Leah has been feeling tired and has had mild lower abdominal pain. She hasn't seen a doctor yet, but after a friend encourages her, she gets tested and is diagnosed with trichomoniasis, a parasitic STD. Which of the following is true about Leah's condition?
options: It will go away without treatment
Trichomoniasis is caused by a virus
It can be treated with antibiotics

question: A 20-year-old male tests positive for HIV, which he likely contracted months earlier. He feels fine but is surprised by the diagnosis. Why is early detection of HIV critical?
options: HIV can be cured if caught early
HIV always shows symptoms right away
Treatment can slow the virus and protect the immune system
The virus is only contagious during symptoms

question: A teenage girl receives the HPV vaccine at school. Her friend asks why she needs a vaccine for something that isn’t dangerous. What is the main reason young people are vaccinated against HPV?
options: HPV can lead to cervical cancer later in life
HPV makes it harder to get pregnant

question: In the menstrual cycle, when do levels of luteinizing hormone rise most dramatically?
The release of LH and FSH by the male pituitary gland results in
What is a zygote?
options: the head region of a sperm that helps a sperm enter an egg
a fertilized egg that has 23 chromosomes from each parent
an area on the egg’s membrane where sperm are able to enter
the whiplike tail of a sperm that enables it to swim to the egg

question: What is a zygote?
options: the head region of a sperm that helps a sperm enter an egg
a fertilized egg that has 23 chromosomes from each parent
an area on the egg’s membrane where sperm are able to enter
the whiplike tail of a sperm that enables it to swim to the egg
